text: [1,2] vs [1;2] is it vcat for both then why have this , syntax baggage at all,lets remove this repetition in next julia version

elements.text: [1,2] vs [1;2] is it vcat for both then why have this , syntax baggage at all,lets remove this repetition in next julia version

text:
They do different things. For instance:
```julia> [[1,], [2,]]
2-element Vector{Vector{Int64}}:
 [1]
 [2]

julia> [[1,]; [2,]]
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 1
 2```

elements.text: They do different things. For instance:

text: Which func call in both is made

elements.text: Which func call in both is made

text:
```julia> Meta.@lower [[1,], [2,]]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.vect(1)
│   %2 = Base.vect(2)
│   %3 = Base.vect(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))

julia> Meta.@lower [[1,]; [2,]]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.vect(1)
│   %2 = Base.vect(2)
│   %3 = Base.vcat(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))```

elements.text:
julia> Meta.@lower [[1,], [2,]]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.vect(1)
│   %2 = Base.vect(2)
│   %3 = Base.vect(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))

julia> Meta.@lower [[1,]; [2,]]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.vect(1)
│   %2 = Base.vect(2)
│   %3 = Base.vcat(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))

text: `[a, b]` is `vect(a, b)` whereas `[a; b]` is `vcat(a, b)`.
Did u read the entire manual

elements.text: Did u read the entire manual

text: I would definitely recommend reading it.
